marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Collection contains legal documents including a statement concerning a roadway survey, 1775; and a letter requesting proof of citizenship for a man impressed on a British warship, 1802.
Collection consists of a business letter from John B. Lohier to Brimmer mentioning mercantile affairs, commodity prices, and business in Washington, N.C.
Collection consists of a receipt book containing mainly routine business receipts with occasional references to slaves and the settlement of an estate.
Collection contains a land grant, 1795, and a letter, 1796, to Brooke from Governor John H. Stone of Md., proposing an interchange of copies of laws among all the states of the Union.
Collection contains an inventory and sales accounts of a merchant.
Accounts of a Hanover County (Va.) planter.

Includes 12 letters from Broderip's brother, humorist Tom Hood, concerning family matters and his literary endeavors. Some letters illustrated with Hood's cartoons. Another correspondent is poet Richard Howitt, who expressed admiration for Broderip's father, poet Thomas Hood. Collection contains family photographs and manuscripts of Broderip's poems and essays. Includes essay on the plight of women employed in British garment and millinery industries.
Vice-president of the United States, 1857-1861, and officer in the Confederate Army.
Letters and a telegram from A. Dudley Mann, William P. Johnston, William Emmet Simms, and others, concerning the presidential elections of 1860 and 1864, and military affairs.
Collection contains Civil War correspondence including a request for money for a furlough and references to conditions of crops at home.
Confederate army officer, assistant adjutant general of the Military District of the West, stationed in Augusta, Ga.

Official correspondence, reports, military dispatches, and orders. Papers concerning the affairs of the Georgia Railroad indicate improper use of government transportation by private individuals; other topics include the disorganization in Mississippi during the last months of the war, detailed accounts of subsistence stores, railroad equipment, troop movements, ordnance depots, and supplies, after Sherman's March. Includes an official report of the medical director, Division of the West. A letter from Leonidas Polk explains why he disobeyed orders at Chickamauga, and one from Simon B. Buckner discusses the organization of the Dept. of East Tennessee. Other correspondents include John F. Branch, Howell Cobb, B.D. Fry, Duff C. Green, E.H. Harris, and J.R. Waddy.
H. M. Bridgman letter to "dear Aunt Brest,"

Describes mission activities, living conditions, and the indigenous people at the Jfumi Mission Station, Natal, South Africa. Other mission stations are referred to as well. Includes some comments regarding the Civil War and personal news.
Thanksgiving Proclamation of Bramlette, governor of Kentucky, on October 17, 1863.
Union soldier, from Cooper (Washington Co.), Maine.

Letters of a Union private, member of the 6th Maine Volunteers, principally concerning crop conditions at home, with some references to his military activities and the reorganization of the Union Army.
Letters to Brooke from various correspondents concerning antiquities of East Suffolk.

Collection contains a letter to Brawley from J. Henry Toole, an African-American of Rock Hill, S.C., seeking a position. There are three letters of recommendation. Also included are papers concerning the claim of Charles P. Petit for an increase in pension.
Philologist and professor at Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md.

Letters from friends and collegues concerning literary and other professional matters. Among the correspondents are Joseph Carhart, Alexander Green, R.H. Hudnal, C.N. Lagley, Lord Northbrook, John Phelps, Charles H. Ross, W.H. Schofield, Edward S. Sheldon, Reed Smith, and Robert Stein.

Papers concerning Briggs' first year in office. Material pertains to problems following World War I, the national banking system, the national budget, and Democratic politics in 1918. Correspondents include J.S. Williams, R.S. Brookings, Homer Cummings, Julius Barnes, Tom Connally, H.J. Drane, and S.O. Bland.
